text: <ALL>Rate of distraction calculation (Figs. 6, 7 and 8) Ideal rate for new bone formation by distraction osteogenesis is known as 1 mm/ day.5,6</ALL>
label: Tissue

text: <ALL>The slower rates may lead to premature consolidation, whereas the faster rates may result in poor regenerate bone formation.</ALL>
label: Tissue

text: <ALL>In simple longitudinal lengthening, the rate of distraction is equal at any point of the corticotomy, however, the rate of distraction at any given portion of the corticotomy varies during angular correction.</ALL>

<ALL>Usually, the gap between corticotomized bone ends is larger on the concave side, therefore, the rate of angular correction should be adjusted so that the rate of distraction of the concave side is closer to 1 mm/day.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>In cases with passive hinge system, the amount of daily angular correction can easily be calculated by the geometric methods using the rule of similar triangles and the rule of concentric circles, and can be expressed as the amount of daily lengthening of motor system.</ALL>

<ALL>In passive hinge system, the ACA is fixed on the frame in Ilizarov system or on the convex side of corticotomy in unilateral fixator system, and angular correction is achieved by changing the length of the motor (Ilizarov system) or the lengthener (unilateral fixator) which rotates the passive hinge.</ALL>
<ALL>However, in active hinge system, angulator directly corrects angular deformity, and the lengthener and translator adjust secondary displacement.</ALL>
<ALL>Therefore, the rate of angular correction cannot be determined by the simple geometric methods used for passive hinge system.</ALL>
<ALL>Regardless of types of fixators, the gap opens larger on the concave side of the deformity after realignment.</ALL>
<ALL>The rate of angular correction also should be adjusted so that the rate of distraction of concave side is 1 mm/day.</ALL>

<ALL>Theoretically, after realignment by Dyna-ATC with adjustment of secondary displacement, the convex side of the corticotomy does not change in length, but the cocave side opens to correct angular deformity.</ALL>
<ALL>The amount of lengthening on the concave side can be calculated with the thickness of the bone at the corticotomy site and the amount of angular deformity (Fig. 6).</ALL>
label: Tissue
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>If the corticotomy is performed on the CORA, no translation deformity happens, however, if not, translation results at the corticotomy site after realignment is achieved.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The amount of translation can be calculated with the distance from the CORA to the corticotomy over the longitudinal bisecting line (lBL) (Fig. 6).</ALL>

<ALL>On the immediate post-operative radiographs, the gap distance of concave side after realignment can be calculated with the expected change in length and translation on the concave side of the corticotomy using the Pythaorean theorem.</ALL>
<ALL>The rate of angular correction should be given as the amount of daily correction angle, but not as the amount of length change of the fixator.</ALL>
<ALL>The angular change of angulator determines the secondary change of length and translation of the corticotomy site.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The amount of secondary deformity during angular correction can be calculated with the thickness of bone at the corticotomy site, the distance between the ACA and the corticotomy, and tan (a/2) (a is the amount of angular correction) (Fig. 6).</ALL>
label: Tissue
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The thickness of the bone at the corticotomy site and the distance between the ACA and the corticotomy do not change, once the corticotomy is performed after Dyna-ATC is applied.</ALL>
label: Tissue
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>Therefore, the amount of secondary deformities changes only with tan (a/2) value.</ALL>
<ALL>If tangent value varies proportionally with changes of angle, the gap distance increases constantly with the given amount of daily correction angle during angular correction.</ALL>

<ALL>If not, the gap distance varies continuously with changes of the angle, therefore, the amount of correction angle should be readjusted everyday to maintain 1 mm/day of distraction rate on the concave side of the corticotomy.</ALL>
<ALL>Fortunately, while the value of tangent angle increases exponentially especially over 45 degrees, tangent function curve is nearly straight, less than 30 degrees (Fig. 7).</ALL>

<ALL>Therefore, in cases with less than 60 degrees of angular deformity, the amount of daily correction angle which permits 1 mm/day of distraction rate on the concave side of the corticotomy can be obtained as the rate of angular correction without daily adjustment during angular correction.</ALL>
<ALL>Once the amount of daily angular correction is determined, the amount of daily length and translation compensation can also be calculated with the amount of daily angular correction.</ALL>

<ALL>Exact adjustment of secondary changes in length and translation at each angular correction opens the concave side of the corticotomy 1 mm per day, but allows minimal gap on the corticotomy of convex side especially in the early stage of angular correction.</ALL>
<ALL>Therefore, it is possible that the corticotomized bone ends of convex side, may abut each other and prevent angular correction or adjustment of secondary translation.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>For the cases where the concomitant lengthening is required, longitudinal lengthening prior to angular correction is recommended.</ALL>
<ALL>Otherwise, about 5 mm pre-lengthening and re-shortening after angular correction could be helpful in avoiding abutment on the convex side of the corticotomy site.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>Inappropriate sequence of angular correction and adjustment of secondary deformities could be one of the causes of the impingement.</ALL>
<ALL>Appropriate sequence of correction is lengthening-translation-angulation with Dyna-ATC on the concave side and angulation-translation-shortening with Dyna-ATC on the convex side.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Stimulation was mainly due to an increase in extracellular GAGs (secreted into culture medium), and to a lesser extent to an increase in peri- and intracellular GAGs.</ALL>

text: <ALL>High-mobility group A2 protein modulates hTERT transcription to promote tumorigenesis.  </ALL>
<ALL>The high-mobility group A2 gene (HMGA2) is one of the most frequently amplified genes in human cancers.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>However, functions of HMGA2 in tumorigenesis are not fully understood due to limited knowledge of its targets in tumor cells.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Our study reveals a novel link between HMGA2 and the regulation of human telomerase reverse transcriptase (hTERT), the catalytic subunit of telomerase, which offers critical insight into how HMGA2 contributes to tumorigenesis.</ALL>
<ALL>The expression of HMGA2 modulates the expression of hTERT, resulting in cells with enhanced telomerase activities and increased telomere length.</ALL>
label: Cell
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>Treatment with suberoylanilide hydroxamide (SAHA), a histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibitor, causes dose-dependent hTERT reporter activation, mimicking HMGA2 overexpression.</ALL>

<ALL>By interacting with Sp1, HMGA2 interferes with the recruitment of HDAC2 to the hTERT proximal promoter, enhancing localized histone H3-K9 acetylation and thereby stimulating hTERT expression and telomerase activity.</ALL>

<ALL>Moreover, HMGA2 knockdown by short hairpin HMGA2 in HepG2 cells leads to progressive telomere shortening and a concurrent decrease of steady-state hTERT mRNA levels, attenuating their ability to form colonies in soft agar.</ALL>
label: Cell
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>Importantly, HMGA2 partially replaces the function of hTERT during the tumorigenic transformation of normal human fibroblasts.</ALL>

text: <ALL>These findings are potentially clinically relevant, because HMGA2 expression is reported to be upregulated in a number of human cancers as telomere maintenance is essential for tumorigenesis.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Complications after plate fixation of phalangeal fractures.</ALL>
<ALL>PURPOSE:</ALL>
<ALL>To assess the complications after plate fixation of phalangeal fractures, their correlation with the type of injury, and the outcome.</ALL>
<ALL>METHODS:</ALL>

<ALL>We retrospectively reviewed the clinical records and the x-rays of 54 consecutive patients with 64 phalangeal fractures treated by open reduction and plate fixation with regard to fracture healing, plate loosening or failure, infection, complex regional pain syndrome, pain, return to work, and range of motion.</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>
<ALL>In 31 out of 54 patients (57%) and 33 out of 64 fractures (52%), one or more major complications occurred.</ALL>

<ALL>Stiffness (definition is composite range of motion of metaphalangeal, proximal interphalangeal, and distal interphalangeal joints added together equaling <180 degrees) contributed the highest number (22 patients, 24 fractures).</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure
MultiTissueStructure
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The complication rates were not different whether the fracture was open or closed, if it was located in the proximal or middle phalanx, the presence or absence of an associated soft tissue lesion, and the patient's occupation.</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSIONS:</ALL>
<ALL>In spite of early mobilization, stiffness is the most frequent complication after open reduction and plate fixation of phalangeal fractures.</ALL>

<ALL>The undue amount of scarring and adhesion may arise from the implant itself or the difficulty in finding the perfect mixture between the minimal surgical invasiveness and a sufficient restoration of skeletal stability.</ALL>
<ALL>Otherwise, plate fixation of unstable and complex phalangeal fractures proved efficient and reliable, although not free of potential problems.</ALL>

text: <ALL>One of the most common signatures of highly malignant tumors is their capacity to metabolize more glucose to lactic acid than their tissues of origin.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Tissue

text: <ALL>Hepatomas exhibiting this phenotype are dependent on the high expression of type II hexokinase, which supplies such tumors with abundant amounts of glucose 6-phosphate, a significant carbon and energy source especially under hypoxic conditions.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Here we report that the distal region of the hepatoma type II hexokinase promoter displays consensus motifs for hypoxia-inducible factor (HIF-1) that overlap E-box sequences known to be related in other gene promoters to glucose response.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Moreover, we show that subjecting transfected hepatoma cells to hypoxic conditions activates the type II hexokinase promoter almost 3-fold, a value that approaches 7-fold in the presence of glucose.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Consistent with these findings is the induction under hypoxic conditions of the HIF-1 protein.</ALL>

<ALL>Reporter gene analyses with a series of nested deletion mutants of the hepatoma type II hexokinase promoter show that a significant fraction of the total activation observed under hypoxic conditions localizes to the distal region where the overlapping HIF-1/E-box sequences are located.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Finally, DNase I footprint analysis with a segment of the promoter containing these elements reveals the binding of several nuclear proteins.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>In summary, these novel studies identify and characterize a marked glucose-modulated activation response of the type II hexokinase gene to hypoxic conditions within highly glycolytic hepatoma cells, a property that may help assure that such cells exhibit a growth and survival advantage over their parental cells of origin.</ALL>

text: <ALL>INTRODUCTION For several years now, virtual microscopy has been utilized in medical teaching, research, proficiency testing, American Board of Pathology examinations, pathology meetings and conferences, and quality assurance programs.</ALL>
<ALL>In diagnostic practice, it is most widely and routinely used in image analysis.</ALL>
<ALL>Some practices are beginning to use it internally (within their group) for frozen section intraoperative consultations and subspecialty consultations due to geographic and time constrains.</ALL>

<ALL>Although diagnostic consultation for expert second opinion is a well-established practice in pathology for glass slides, similar consultation via virtual microscopy poses multiple controversial issues such as licensing, liability, security, reimbursement, and scanning quality and its validation.</ALL>
<ALL>Regulations and standardization are not yet in place that pathologists can use to allay these fears.</ALL>

<ALL>Nevertheless, if the virtual microscopy scans are of optimal quality, these can be simply substituted for glass slides and a microscope while maintaining all other practice guidelines for second opinion consultation.</ALL>
<ALL>Additionally, the cost and maintenance of scanning equipment is not currently affordable to most practitioners and consultants.</ALL>

<ALL>A practice model that offers tertiary consultation in gastrointestinal (GI) and liver pathology is presented that eliminates the cost and maintenance of scanners by the consultants and clients, minimizes the need for review of glass slides, facilitates clinicopathological and radiological correlation and serves the need of clients who need timely help with challenging liver and GI cases and to obtain expert opinion for dysplasia in Barrett's and ulcerative colitis surveillance biopsies required by the American Gastroenterology Association (AGA).</ALL>

text: <ALL>A frequently cited theory for the pathogenesis of neovascularization in diabetic retinopathy is that retinal hypoxia and/or ischemia release a factor which stimulates neovascularization.</ALL>

text: <ALL>To the authors' knowledge, there is no direct in vivo evidence in the human proving this theory.</ALL>
<ALL>One hundred and twenty-two diabetic subjects were studied to see whether worsening retinopathy was associated with changes in conjunctival oxygen tension (pO2).</ALL>

text: <ALL>Diabetics without retinopathy had a conjunctival pO2 which was similar to an age-matched normal population.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>Diabetics with only background retinopathy had a significantly lower conjunctival pO2 than those without retinopathy (P less than 0.01).</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>Diabetics with proliferative retinopathy showed a conjunctival pO2 that was significantly lower than either of the first two groups (P less than 0.05).</ALL>

text: <ALL>The lowest value of all was found in patients with rubeosis iridis.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Antimicrobial prophylaxis in vaginal gynecologic surgery: a prospective randomized study comparing amoxicillin-clavulanic acid with cefazolin.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The aim of this prospective, randomized study was to compare amoxicillin-clavulanic acid with cefazolin as ultra-short term prophylaxis in vaginal gynecologic surgery.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>It was conducted at the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, University of Bari.</ALL>
<ALL>Patients were randomly allocated to receive amoxicillin-clavulanic acid (2.2 g)</ALL>
<ALL>[Group A] or cefazolin (2 g)</ALL>
<ALL>[Group B] as a single dose 30 minutes before surgery.</ALL>
<ALL>Each patient was assessed daily until discharge to evidence febrile status and the presence of infections at the operative site, urinary tract and respiratory tract.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>In the amoxicillin-clavulanic acid (Group A) and cefazolin (Group B) groups, overall 88 and 90 patients, respectively, were evaluable for prophylactic efficacy at hospital discharge.</ALL>

<ALL>Infectious complications were infrequent in both arms, with febrile morbidity occurring in 4 (4.5%) and 16 (8.9%) patients respectively in the amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and cefazolin groups (p=0.016).</ALL>

<ALL>Urinary tract infections were higher but not significantly in the amoxicillin-clavulanic acid group (6.8% versus 4.4 %), whereas asymptomatic bacteriuria was detected in 2.2% of the patients in both groups.</ALL>
<ALL>There was no respiratory tract infection or septic death in either group.</ALL>
<ALL>It is concluded that ultra-short term prophylaxis with both amoxicillin-clavulanic acid and cefazolin is safe and effective in elective vaginal gynecologic surgery.</ALL>

text: <ALL>[Epidemiology of respiratory allergy in children].</ALL>

<ALL>Epidemiology of paediatric respiratory allergic disorders allows the approach to causal and preventive risk factors by studying groups or sub groups of children in different locations and under different conditions.</ALL>
<ALL>This is, however, complicated by the lack of consensus on disease definitions, which renders comparisons between studies difficult.</ALL>

<ALL>Atopy is usually defined by the presence of positive skin tests (wheal size of at least a mean diameter > or = 3 mm), by the presence of specific IgE, or by the presence of increased total IgE (> or = 100 UI/mL).</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Infantile asthma is not well defined, complicated by the high prevalence of bronchiolitis; one thus questions between wheezing or wheezy bronchitis.</ALL>
<ALL>Prevalence is high: among early wheezers, two populations will be defined by the medium term evolution: transient wheezers and persistent wheezers.</ALL>
<ALL>Risk factors for these two conditions are different.</ALL>

<ALL>Childhood asthma may be defined by the diagnosis of asthma (specific but fairly non-sensitive), by asthmatic symptoms (wheezing, waking by an attack of shortness of breath) (sensitive but not very specific), or by the combination of symptoms and airway hyperresponsiveness.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The ISAAC study has standardised a questionnaire to assess the prevalence of asthma.</ALL>
<ALL>The preliminary results show that there are wide variations across the world.</ALL>
<ALL>The prevalence is low in Africa and Asia, intermediate in Europe, and high in Anglo-Saxon countries.</ALL>
<ALL>The prevalence of asthma has gradually increased over the past 20 years in developed countries.</ALL>
<ALL>Asthma and atopy are closely associated in children.</ALL>
<ALL>Risk factors are genetic, associated with sex and environmental factors.</ALL>
<ALL>Among these, allergic sensitisation is associated with the degree of exposure to allergens.</ALL>
<ALL>Westernization of way of life is associated with increased prevalence of atopy, allergic rhinitis and asthma.</ALL>
<ALL>Atopy seems inversely correlated to certain infections.</ALL>
<ALL>Passive smoking is clearly associated with early wheezing.</ALL>
<ALL>This and atmospheric pollution aggravate childhood asthma.</ALL>
<ALL>However, the inducing role of pollution on asthma is still controversial.</ALL>

<ALL>Of the 456 eligible and analyzable patients (parent cohort), adequate archival diagnostic tissue specimens from 108 patients were available for MDM2 analysis (MDM2 cohort).</ALL>

text: <ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>

<ALL>The ACIS index, using a cutoff point defined by the median value, < or = 3% versus > 3%, was related to 5-year DM rates in univariate analyses (32.6% vs. 45.8%; P = 0.057) and MVA (P = 0.06).</ALL>
<ALL>The intensity of MDM2 staining was not significant.</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSIONS: MDM2 expression quantified by image analysis was weakly associated with DM.</ALL>
<ALL>The cohort examined was relatively small and with larger patient numbers, MDM2 overexpression may emerge as a more significant covariate.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Here, in order to characterize the role of the promoter that drives DSCR-1s expression in mediating inducible expression in vivo and to determine the functional relevance of DSCR-1s in inflammation, we targeted a DNA construct containing 1.7 kb of the human DSCR1s promoter coupled to the lacZ reporter to the hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase (Hprt) locus of mice.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Bevacizumab is a humanized immunoglobulin G1 monoclonal antibody to vascular endothelial growth factor that has been shown to have activity in malignant gliomas when combined with irinotecan.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The authors report on a case series of 13 patients with recurrent heavily pretreated malignant glioma that was treated with the combination of bevacizumab and irinotecan.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>METHODS:</ALL>
<ALL>Standard therapy with primary resection followed by adjuvant chemotherapy and radiation had failed in all patients.</ALL>
<ALL>The median number of therapies applied, including initial surgery, was 5 (range 3-7 therapies).</ALL>
<ALL>Nine patients were started on bevacizumab at a dose of 5 mg/m2 every 2 weeks.</ALL>
<ALL>Four patients received bevacizumab at a dose of 10 mg/m2; irinotecan was given at a dose of 125 mg/m2 every week for 3 weeks.</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS: Of the 13 treated patients, 10 (77%) had a radiologically demonstrated partial response and 3 (23%) had stable disease.</ALL>
<ALL>Six patients (46%) had a clinical response.</ALL>
<ALL>The median time to disease progression while on treatment was 24 weeks.</ALL>
<ALL>The median overall survival was 27 weeks.</ALL>
<ALL>The disease progressed in 8 patients, despite an initial response.</ALL>
<ALL>Five patients are still responding to therapy.</ALL>
<ALL>Six of the 8 patients whose disease progressed have died.</ALL>
<ALL>Bevacizumab was discontinued in 2 patients because of nonfatal intracranial bleeding.</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSIONS:</ALL>

<ALL>The combination of bevacizumab and irinotecan is safe and has excellent activity even in this relapsed, heavily pretreated population of patients with high-grade malignant glioma, most of whom would not be candidates for clinical trials.</ALL>

text: <ALL>[Diagnostic value of DNA, RNA and proliferating cell nuclear antigen examination in malignant pleural effusions by flow cytometry].</ALL>
<ALL>OBJECTIVE:</ALL>

<ALL>To study the diagnostic value of DNA, RNA and proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) examination in malignant effusion by multiparametric flow cytometry, and therefore to provide proof for clinical application.</ALL>

<ALL>METHODS: Forty seven patients with pleural effusions in our hospital from August 2003 to February 2004 were divided into two groups: 19 suffering from benign pleural effusions and 28 from malignant effusions confirmed by pathologic examination.</ALL>
<ALL>The cells for diagnosis were divided into four groups stained by PI (Propidium-iodide), PY (Pyronin), PCNA-FITC and PCNA-mouse-alpha-2a.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>The specimens were analyzed by a flow cytometer (FacS Caliber, Becton Dickinson).</ALL>
<ALL>The sensitivity and the specificity of each examination and combined examination were calculated by statistic software SPSS 13.0.</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS: (1) The expression of DI, RI, and PI in benign pleural effusion was 1.03 +/- 0.06, 10.03 +/- 0.54, and (4.86 +/-</ALL>
<ALL>0.72)%, respectively, and those in malignant ones was 1.26 +/- 0.17, 11.65 +/- 1.45, and (11.97 +/- 1.50)%, respectively, the difference being statistically significant.</ALL>
<ALL>The cutoff value of DI, RI and PI was 1.10%, 10.75% and 4.56%, and the sensitivity of DI examination was 89.3%, 78.6%, 75.0%, and the specificity was 89.5%, 98.5%, 84.2%, respectively.</ALL>
<ALL>(2)</ALL>
<ALL>In 6 cases suffering from malignant pleural effusions, RI was positive but DI was negative, indicating that DI combined with RI examination was better than DI examination alone.</ALL>

<ALL>(3) In 5 cases suffering from malignant pleural effusions confirmed by tissue examination, the cytology was negative, but the result of DI and RI was abnormal, indicating that flow cytometry was complementary to pathologic examination.</ALL>
label: Tissue

text: <ALL>(4) The sensitivity of DI + RI, DI + PI, RI + PI and DI + RI + PI combined examination was 98.2%, 89.3%, 89.3%, 92.9%; the specificity was 84.2%, 89.5%, 84.2%, 94.2% respectively.</ALL>
<ALL>The results demonstrated that DI + RI + PI combined examination was the best, which showed the least false negative and false positive results.</ALL>
<ALL>The sensitivity of DI + RI combined examination was 98.2%, but the specificity was 84.2%, the false positive rate being higher than DI + RI + PI combined examination.</ALL>
<ALL>In none of the benign pleural effusions was the DI + RI + PI higher than the cutoff value, suggesting that combined examination can exclude benign pleural effusions.</ALL>

<ALL>CONCLUSIONS: DNA, RNA and PCNA examinations by flow cytometry are of value in the diagnosis of malignant effusion, especially for cases which can not be diagnosed by cytological examination.</ALL>
<ALL>DI + RI + PI combined examination showed better results with the lowest false negative and false positive rates.</ALL>

text: <ALL>The mammalian proto-oncogene Cbl and its cellular homologues in Caenorhabditis elegans (Sli-1) and Drosophila (D-Cbl) are negative regulators of some growth factor receptor signaling pathways.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Herein we show that Cbl can negatively regulate another signaling molecule, namely theSrc-family kinase Hck by targeting it for degradation.</ALL>

<ALL>Hck-mediated cellular transformation of murine fibroblasts is reverted by ectopic expression of a membrane-anchored allele of Cbl as assessed by the cellular morphology, suppression of anchorage independent growth, and an overall reduction in the total tyrosine phosphorylation levels within the cells.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell
CellularComponent
Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>The expression of Cbl at the plasma membrane targets both Hck and itself for ubiquitination and degradation, requiring an intact RING finger.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>Pharmacological inhibition of the proteasome prevents the degradation of Hck correlating with an increase in the phosphotyrosine levels within the cells.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Activated Hck and membrane-anchored Cbl are present in similar subcellular localizations and co-immunoprecipitate, suggesting that their interaction is required for subsequent ubiquitination and degradation.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>Interestingly, both constitutively active and kinase-inactive Hck interact with and are targeted for degradation by Cbl.</ALL>

<ALL>This work illustrates alternate means to regulate Src-family kinases, and suggests that Cbl may be able to suppress many signaling pathways that are activated in various proliferative syndromes including cancer.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Adaptive landscapes and emergent phenotypes: why do cancers have high glycolysis?</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Investigating the causes of increased aerobic glycolysis in tumors (Warburg Effect) has gone in and out of fashion many times since it was first described almost a century ago.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The field is currently in ascendance due to two factors.</ALL>
<ALL>Over a million FDG-PET studies have unequivocally identified increased glucose uptake as a hallmark of metastatic cancer in humans.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>These observations, combined with new molecular insights with HIF-1alpha and c-myc, have rekindled an interest in this important phenotype.</ALL>
<ALL>A preponderance of work has been focused on the molecular mechanisms underlying this effect, with the expectation that a mechanistic understanding may lead to novel therapeutic approaches.</ALL>

<ALL>There is also an implicit assumption that a mechanistic understanding, although fundamentally reductionist, will nonetheless lead to a more profound teleological understanding of the need for altered metabolism in invasive cancers.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>In this communication, we describe an alternative approach that begins with teleology; i.e. adaptive landscapes and selection pressures that promote emergence of aerobic glycolysis during the somatic evolution of invasive cancer.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Mathematical models and empirical observations are used to define the adaptive advantage of aerobic glycolysis that would explain its remarkable prevalence in human cancers.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>These studies have led to the hypothesis that increased consumption of glucose in metastatic lesions is not used for substantial energy production via Embden-Meyerhoff glycolysis, but rather for production of acid, which gives the cancer cells a competitive advantage for invasion.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cell

text: <ALL>Alternative hypotheses, wherein the glucose is used for generation of reducing equivalents (NADPH) or anabolic precursors (ribose) are also discussed.</ALL>
<ALL>Endogenous thyroid hormones modulate pituitary somatotroph differentiation during chicken embryonic development.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Growth hormone cell differentiation normally occurs between day 14 and day 16 of chicken embryonic development.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>We reported previously that corticosterone (CORT) could induce somatotroph differentiation in vitro and in vivo and that thyroid hormones could act in combination with CORT to further augment the abundance of somatotrophs in vitro.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>The objective of the present study was to test our hypothesis that endogenous thyroid hormones regulate the abundance of somatotrophs during chicken embryonic development.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Plasma samples were collected on embryonic day (e) 9-14.</ALL>
<ALL>We found that plasma CORT and thyroid hormone levels increased progressively in mid-embryogenesis to e 13 or e 14, immediately before normal somatotroph differentiation.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Administration of thyroxine (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) into the albumen of fertile eggs on e 11 increased somatotroph proportions prematurely on e 13 in the developing chick embryos in vivo.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Furthermore, administration of methimazole, the thyroid hormone synthesis inhibitor, on e 9 inhibited somatotroph differentiation in vivo, as assessed on e 14; this suppression was completely reversed by T3 replacement on e 11.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Since we reported that T3 alone was ineffective in vitro, we interpret these findings to indicate that the effects of treatments in vivo were due to interactions with endogenous glucocorticoids.</ALL>

<ALL>These results indicate that treatment with exogenous thyroid hormones can modulate somatotroph abundance and that endogenous thyroid hormone synthesis likely contributes to normal somatotroph differentiation.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Ectopic decorin expression up-regulates VEGF expression in mouse cerebral endothelial cells via activation of the transcription factors Sp1, HIF1alpha, and Stat3.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>We demonstrate that a proteoglycan decorin (DCN) up-regulates the vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) expression with activation of VEGF regulating transcription factors Sp1, hypoxia-inducible factor 1alpha (HIF1alpha), and signal transducer and activator of transcription 3 (Stat3) via epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR), mitogen-activated protein kinase extracellular signal-regulated kinase 1/2 (ERK1/2), and protein kinase B (AKT) pathways in DCN transfected mouse cerebral endothelial (MCE) cells.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Treatment with pharmacological inhibitors and small interfering RNAs reveal that induction and activation of Sp1, HIF1alpha, and Stat3 facilitate their nuclear localization and binding to their specific motifs of the VEGF promoter and induce VEGF expression via two independent pathways, DCN/EGFR/phosphoinositide-3 kinase/AKT and DCN/EGFR/ERK1/2, respectively, in DCN synthesizing MCE cells.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
Cell

text: <ALL>The cell type specific glycosylation protects Sp1 and HIF1alpha from proteosome degradation and plays an important and novel role in the regulation of VEGF in DCN transfected MCE cells.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>Induction of gelatinases (matrix metalloproteinase 2 and 9), the serine protease tissue plasminogen activator and plasmin by DCN transfection in MCE cells leads to extracellular proteolysis and to release of matrix-bound VEGF and activation of angiogenesis.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>In this study, we demonstrate that two independent downstream signal pathways, DCN/EGFR/ERK1/2 and DCN/EGFR/phosphoinositide-3 kinase/AKT, mediate up-regulation and activation of transcription factors of VEGF such as HIF1alpha, Stat3, and Sp1 and increase VEGF transcription and angiogenesis in MCE cells.</ALL>

text: <ALL>An evaluation of low molecular weight heparin and hyperbaric oxygen treatment in the prevention of intra-abdominal adhesions and wound healing.</ALL>
<ALL>BACKGROUND:</ALL>
<ALL>Abdominal surgery can lead to intra-abdominal adhesions with significant morbidity and mortality.</ALL>

<ALL>To prevent adhesions, an experimental study was planned to designate the effects of low molecular weight (LMW) heparins and hyperbaric oxygen (HBO) therapy both on the formation of adhesions and wound healing.</ALL>
<ALL>METHODS: Thirty-eight Wistar albino rats underwent laparotomy to cause intra-abdominal adhesions by mechanical abrasion of the cecum and ethanol application.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The rats were divided into 4 groups.</ALL>
<ALL>In the control group (group 1) no further management was undertaken.</ALL>
<ALL>Group 2 was treated by Enoxaparine Na, group 3 received HBO therapy, and group 4 was given both enoxaparine Na and HBO treatment.</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>
<ALL>There was a statistically significant difference between the control and enoxaparine Na groups regarding adhesions.</ALL>
<ALL>Statistically significant differences were observed between groups 1 and 4 and between groups 1 and 3 regarding the hydroxyproline content of the abdominal wounds.</ALL>
<ALL>In the pathologic analysis of the abdominal wounds, there was no statistically significant difference between any of the groups, including the control group, regarding inflammation.</ALL>
<ALL>Statistically significant differences were observed regarding angiogenesis between the control group and groups 3 and 4.</ALL>

<ALL>There was also a statistically significant difference regarding fibrosis between groups 1 and 4. CONCLUSIONS: Enoxaparine Na decreased intra-abdominal adhesions, and HBO therapy had no beneficial effect on adhesions.</ALL>
<ALL>Enoxaparine Na had no harmful effects on wound healing, and HBO therapy increased the process of wound healing.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Multiple myeloma, an incurable plasma cell malignancy, is characterized by altered cellular metabolism and resistance to apoptosis.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>Recent connections between glucose metabolism and resistance to apoptosis provide a compelling rationale for targeting metabolic changes in cancer.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>In this study, we have examined the ability of the purine analogue 8-aminoadenosine to acutely reduce glucose consumption by regulating localization and expression of key glucose transporters.</ALL>
<ALL>Myeloma cells counteracted the metabolic stress by activating autophagy.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Co-treatment with inhibitors of autophagy results in marked enhancement of cell death.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Glucose consumption by drug-resistant myeloma cells was unaffected by 8-aminoadenosine, and accordingly, no activation of autophagy was observed.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>However, these cells can be sensitized to 8-aminoadenosine under glucose-limiting conditions.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>The prosurvival autophagic response of myeloma to nutrient deprivation or to nucleoside analogue treatment has not been described previously.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>This study establishes the potential of metabolic targeting as a broader means to kill and sensitize myeloma and identifies a compound that can achieve this goal.</ALL>

text: <ALL>We previously reported that the murine fibroblast cell line LTA is tumorigenic but non-metastatic, and is non-responsive to a transfected H-ras oncogene.</ALL>

text: <ALL>In contrast, NIH 3T3 cells are non-tumorigenic but are ras-responsive and become metastatic when transfected with ras.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Here we examined expression of type IV collagenases in parental LTA and NIH 3T3 cells (with and without ras) and four metastatic LTA x NIH 3T3 hybrids (also with and without ras).</ALL>

text: <ALL>Parental NIH 3T3-derived cells had both 72 kDa and 92 kDa gelatinase activities, and LTA-derived cells had either aberrantly sized approximately 90 kDa activity alone or neither enzyme activity.</ALL>

text: <ALL>All four metastatic hybrids expressed 60-72 kDa gelatinase activity, while three of them also had 92 kDa activity and one had only minimal 92 kDa activity.</ALL>

<ALL>High-Dose celecoxib and metronomic "low-dose" cyclophosphamide is an effective and safe therapy in patients with relapsed and refractory aggressive histology non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>PURPOSE:</ALL>
<ALL>Angiogenesis is increased in aggressive histology non-Hodgkin's lymphoma and may be a target with selective cyclooxygenase-2 inhibition and metronomic chemotherapy.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</ALL>

<ALL>We assessed response, toxicity, and biomarkers of angiogenesis to low-dose cyclophosphamide (50 mg p.o. o.d.) and high-dose celecoxib (400 mg p.o. b.i.d.) in adult patients with relapsed or refractory aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in a multicenter phase II prospective study.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>RESULTS: Thirty-two of 35 patients (median age, 62 years) are evaluable for response.</ALL>

<ALL>Patients had primarily relapsed diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (63%) were heavily pretreated (median of three regimens) and high risk (79% international prognostic index,  greater than or=2) and 34% were relapsed after autologous stem cell transplant.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cell

text: <ALL>With a median follow-up of 8.4 months, the overall best response rate is 37% (2 complete clinical response/complete clinical response unconfirmed and 9 partial response), with 22% achieving stable disease.</ALL>
<ALL>Median overall and progression-free survivals are 14.4 and 4.7 months, respectively.</ALL>
<ALL>The median response duration was 8.2 months.</ALL>
<ALL>The most common toxicity was skin rash (40%); myelosuppression and gastrointestinal side effects were uncommon.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Three patients developed deep vein thromboses and two heavily pretreated patients developed treatment-related acute myelogenous leukemia or myelodysplasia after 3.7 and 12 months of therapy.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Circulating endothelial cells and their precursors declined and remained low in responders, whereas plasma vascular endothelial growth factor trended to decline in responding patients but increase in nonresponders.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>Trough celecoxib levels achieved targeted "antiangiogenic" levels.</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSIONS:</ALL>
<ALL>Low-dose cyclophosphamide and high-dose celecoxib is well tolerated and active in pretreated aggressive non-Hodgkin's lymphoma.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Close surveillance for arterial and venous thrombotic events is recommended.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>The decline in circulating endothelial cells and their precursors suggests that this combination may be working by inhibiting angiogenesis but should be validated in a larger patient sample.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Cognitive function and number of teeth in a community-dwelling elderly population without dementia.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Although the number of sound or decayed teeth has been reported to be associated with cognitive function in elderly populations with dementia, little is known about this association in elderly populations without dementia.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>We evaluated this relationship, with adjustment for confounding factors, in Japanese populations of 60-year-old (n = 270; 120 males and 150 females) and 65-year-old (n = 123; 57 males and 66 females) individuals residing in Fukuoka Prefecture of Japan.</ALL>
<ALL>Dental examinations were performed in all subjects, along with the Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) for assessing cognitive function.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Among the total of 393 subjects, the mean MMSE score was 27.9 +/- 1.9, and 391 subjects scored 24 or higher.</ALL>
<ALL>The mean numbers of sound and decayed teeth were 12.0 +/- 6.3 and 0.5 +/- 1.2, respectively.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Associations were found between the numbers of sound and decayed teeth and MMSE in total subjects and males, but not in females, by multiple regression analysis adjusted for gender, age, level of education, marital status, smoking, alcohol drinking, working status, systolic blood pressure and blood glucose.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>An association was also found between MMSE and the number of sound teeth in a logistic regression analysis.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>In conclusion, associations were found between normal-range cognitive function and the numbers of sound and decayed teeth, after adjustment for various confounding factors, in an elderly Japanese population.</ALL>

label: Cancer

text: <ALL>PURPOSE:</ALL>

<ALL>We previously found that cellular FLICE-inhibitory protein (c-FLIP), caspase 8, and tumor necrosis factor-related apoptosis-inducing ligand (TRAIL) receptor 2 (DR5) are major regulators of cell viability and chemotherapy-induced apoptosis in colorectal cancer.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cancer

text: <ALL>In this study, we determined the prognostic significance of c-FLIP, caspase 8, TRAIL and DR5 expression in tissues from patients with stage II and III colorectal cancer.</ALL>
label: Tissue
Cancer

text: <ALL>EXPERIMENTAL DESIGN:</ALL>
<ALL>Tissue microarrays were constructed from matched normal and tumor tissue derived from patients (n = 253) enrolled in a phase</ALL>
label: Tissue
Tissue

text: <ALL>III trial of adjuvant 5-fluorouracil-based chemotherapy versus postoperative observation alone.</ALL>
<ALL>TRAIL, DR5, caspase 8, and c-FLIP expression levels were determined by immunohistochemistry.</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>

<ALL>Colorectal tumors displayed significantly higher expression levels of c-FLIP (P < 0.001), caspase 8 (P = 0.01), and DR5 (P < 0.001), but lower levels of TRAIL (P < 0.001) compared with matched normal tissue.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Tissue

text: <ALL>In univariate analysis, higher TRAIL expression in the tumor was associated with worse overall survival (P = 0.026), with a trend to decreased relapse-free survival (RFS; P = 0.06), and higher tumor c-FLIP expression was associated with a significantly decreased RFS (P = 0.015).</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>Using multivariate predictive modeling for RFS in all patients and including all biomarkers, age, treatment, and stage, we found that the model was significant when the mean tumor c-FLIP expression score and disease stage were included (P < 0.001).</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>As regards overall survival, the overall model was predictive when both TRAIL expression and disease stage were included (P < 0.001).</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSIONS: High c-FLIP and TRAIL expression may be independent adverse prognostic markers in stage II and III colorectal cancer and might identify patients most at risk of relapse.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Photodynamic therapy with verteporfin for subfoveal choroidal neovascularization secondary to pathologic myopia: long-term study.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>PURPOSE:</ALL>
<ALL>To assess the safety and effectiveness of photodynamic therapy (PDT) with verteporfin for subfoveal choroidal neovascularization (CNV) secondary to pathologic myopia (PM).</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>METHODS: Sixty-two patients (62 eyes) with PM underwent PDT according to the guidelines of the Verteporfin in Photodynamic Therapy Study.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Clinical evaluations performed at all study visits included measurement of best-corrected Snellen visual acuity, slit-lamp biomicroscopy, and fundus fluorescein angiography.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>Patients were followed up at 1 month and 3 months after treatment and thereafter at 3-month intervals.</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>

<ALL>The final visual acuity of the study patients, after a median follow-up of 31 months, improved by  greater than or=1 Snellen lines in 8 patients (13%), deteriorated in 20 (32%), and remained stable in 34 (55%).</ALL>
<ALL>The baseline visual acuity was similar in the various study groups.</ALL>
<ALL>The final mean visual acuity in group A (55 years of age or younger) was 20/80 and significantly (P=0.006) better than that (20/138) in group B (older than 55 years of age).</ALL>

<ALL>The mean final visual acuity in eyes with higher refractive error at baseline (greater than -17 diopters) was significantly better (P=0.014) than that in eyes with lower refractive error (-6 to -10 diopters).</ALL>
label: Organ
Organ

text: <ALL>CNV size did not affect visual outcomes.</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSION: PDT preserves vision in patients with CNV associated with PM.</ALL>
<ALL>Younger patients and eyes with higher refractive error appear more likely to benefit from PDT with verteporfin.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Vascular endothelial growth factor-B and vascular endothelial growth factor-C expression in renal cell carcinomas: regulation by the von Hippel-Lindau gene and hypoxia.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Angiogenesis is essential for tumor growth and metastasis.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>It is regulated by numerous angiogenic factors, one of the most important being vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF).</ALL>
<ALL>Recently VEGF-B and VEGF-C, two new VEGF family members, have been identified that bind to the tyrosine kinase receptors flt-1 (VEGFR1), KDR (VEGFR2), and flt-4 (VEGFR3).</ALL>
<ALL>Although the importance of VEGF-A has been shown in renal carcinomas, the contribution of these new ligands in kidney tumors is not clear.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>We have, therefore, measured the mRNA level of VEGF-B and VEGF-C together with their receptors by RNase protection assay (RPA) in 26 normal kidney samples and 45 renal cell cancers.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure
Cancer

text: <ALL>We observed a significant up-regulation of VEGF-B (P = 0.002) but not VEGF-C (P = 0.3) in neoplastic kidney compared with normal tissues.</ALL>
label: Organ
Tissue

text: <ALL>In addition, although VEGF receptors were higher in tumors than normal kidney, there was a significant up-regulation of only flt-1 (P = 0.003) but not KDR (P = 0.12) or flt-4 (P = 0.09).</ALL>
label: Cancer
Organ

text: <ALL>There was also a significant correlation between VEGF-C and both of its receptors flt-4 (P = 0.006) and KDR (P = 0.03) but no association between VEGF-B and its receptor flt-1 (P = 0.23).</ALL>

<ALL>A significant increase was observed in flt-1 (P  less than  0.001), KDR (P = 0.02), and flt-4 (P = 0.01) but not VEGF-B (P = 0.82) or VEGF-C (P = 0.52) expression in clear cell compared with chromophil (papillary) carcinomas.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cancer

text: <ALL>No significant association was demonstrated between VEGF-B, VEGF-C, flt-1, KDR, and flt-4 with patient sex, patient age, or tumor size (P  greater than  0.05).</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The effect of von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) gene and hypoxia on VEGF-B and VEGF-C expression in the renal carcinoma cell line 786-0 transfected with wild-type and mutant VHL was determined by growing cells under 21% O2- and 0.1% O2.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>In wild-type VHL cells, whereas VEGF-A was significantly up-regulated under hypoxic compared with normoxic conditions (P  less than  0.001), expression of VEGF-C was reduced (P  less than  0.002).</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Nevertheless, the repression of VEGF-C was lost in mutant VHL cell lines under hypoxia.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>In contrast VEGF-B was not regulated by VHL despite clear up-regulation in vivo.</ALL>
<ALL>These findings strongly support an enhanced role for this pathway in clear cell carcinomas by regulating angiogenesis and/or lymphangiogenesis.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The study shows that clear cell tumors are able to up-regulate angiogenic growth factor receptors more efficiently than chromophil (papillary), that clear cell tumors can use pathways independent of VHL to regulate angiogenesis, and that this combined regulation may account for their more aggressive phenotype, which suggests that targeting VEGFR1 (flt-l) may be particularly effective in these tumor types.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) in seizures: a double-edged sword.</ALL>
<ALL>Vascular endothelial growth factor (VEGF) is a vascular growth factor which induces angiogenesis (the development of new blood vessels), vascular permeability, and inflammation.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure
MultiTissueStructure
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>In brain, receptors for VEGF have been localized to vascular endothelium, neurons, and glia.</ALL>
label: Organ
Tissue
Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>VEGF is upregulated after hypoxic injury to the brain, which can occur during cerebral ischemia or high-altitude edema, and has been implicated in the blood-brain barrier breakdown associated with these conditions.</ALL>
label: Organ
Organ
MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>Given its recently-described role as an inflammatory mediator, VEGF could also contribute to the inflammatory responses observed in cerebral ischemia.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>After seizures, blood-brain barrier breakdown and inflammation is also observed in brain, albeit on a lower scale than that observed after stroke.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure
Organ

text: <ALL>Recent evidence has suggested a role for inflammation in seizure disorders.</ALL>
<ALL>We have described striking increases in VEGF protein in both neurons and glia after pilocarpine-induced status epilepticus in the brain.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell
Organ

text: <ALL>Increases in VEGF could contribute to the blood-brain barrier breakdown and inflammation observed after seizures.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>However, VEGF has also been shown to be neuroprotective across several experimental paradigms, and hence could potentially protect vulnerable cells from damage associated with seizures.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Therefore, the role of VEGF after seizures could be either protective or destructive.</ALL>
<ALL>Although only further research will determine the exact nature of VEGF's role after seizures, preliminary data indicate that VEGF plays a protective role after seizures.</ALL>
<ALL>8.2.</ALL>

<ALL>Species Differences in PPARalpha-Associated Signaling The PPARalpha isotype has prime importance for studies with animal models to predict the effects of hepatic PPs in humans, because PPARalpha agonists induce seemingly quite different actions in rodents and humans</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Originally, as the name indicates, PPARs were studied because of their ability to bind PPs and consequently induce PP-metabolizing enzymes.</ALL>
<ALL>In rats and mice, but not in humans, PPs such as hypolipidemic drugs, industrial plasticizers, and herbicides are non-genotoxic carcinogens that cause liver tumors [54].</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>In humans, these drugs function to maintain lipid homeostasis and do not induce peroxisome proliferation.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>Thus, the toxicity and carcinogenicity of PPs are highly species specific</ALL>
<ALL>The species differences may be attributable to lower PPAR mRNA expression levels in h-hepatocytes compared with rodent cells [56, 57].</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>Alternatively, or additionally, species differences may be the result of different sensitivities of the genes associated with the peroxisome proliferation response to low levels of PPs, owing to structural differences in PPARalpha [54].</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>There are both similarities and differences in responses to xenobiotics among not only different species (interspecies) but also individuals of the same species (intraspecies).</ALL>
<ALL>Interspecific PPARalpha diversity between rodents and humans is well known and has been studied with respect to drug metabolism.</ALL>
<ALL>NR subfamily 1 members have at least two functions in mammals.</ALL>
<ALL>One is to regulate peroxisome proliferation through binding to PPAR response elements (PPREs) in the promoters of genes such as ACO [58, 59], bifunctional dehydrogenase/hydratase (BFE)</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>[60], and microsomal CYP4A1</ALL>
<ALL>The other is to modulate the serum cholesterol level by targeting genes such as the lipoprotein lipase gene [62] and the apolipoprotein regulating genes AI, AII, and CII [63].</ALL>

<ALL>The former mechanism appears to function in rodents, but not in humans, and is responsible for the induction of peroxisome proliferation and hepatocarcinogenesis, whereas the latter mechanism controls basic lipid metabolism in both rodents and humans [56].</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>This species difference in xenobiotic receptor/ligand signaling may be attributable to differences in the expression level of a receptor, or to differences in receptor/ligand binding affinity, and causes difficulty in determining responses in humans based on rodent data [56].</ALL>
<ALL>5.</ALL>
<ALL>Conclusion RLs are new actors in animal and plant defense and their low toxicity and biodegradability make them promising molecules to be used against pathogens.</ALL>
<ALL>In this respect, there are some clues now available for the success of RL applications in greenhouses to fight phytopathogens.</ALL>
<ALL>A better understanding of RL mode of action, especially their perception and the signaling pathways activated, will be very important to potentiate their beneficial effects in plants.</ALL>
<ALL>RLs have a dual mode of action: they are antimicrobial and also stimulate plant defense responses.</ALL>
<ALL>This dual property is probably very important for the efficiency of new biopesticides.</ALL>
<ALL>In animals, the use of RLs is also at an advanced stage.</ALL>
<ALL>RLs are successfully used as antimicrobial agents, especially for skin disease treatment.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Deep insight into the physiochemical effects of RLs and their biological importance would reveal new dimensions in the fields of research like agriculture and medicine, precisely in plant defense, disease control and pathogenesis.</ALL>
<ALL>An understanding of bacterial genera producing RLs that are not yet well studied would provide light on these fascinating aspects.</ALL>
<ALL>Overexpression of Bax inhibitor-1 (BI-1) induces cell transformation in NIH3T3 cells.  </ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>BI-1 (Bax inhibitor-1), an apoptosis-inhibiting gene belonging to the Bcl-2 protein family, plays an important role in mitochondrial apoptosis pathway to suppress Bax-induced apoptosis.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>To investigate the potential role of BI-1 in promoting cell growth and tumorigenesis, in the present study we overexpressed the BI-1 gene in NIH3T3 cells using the lentivirus-mediated gene expression system.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>Our in vitro studies showed that NIH3T3 cells overexpressing BI-1 displayed a significantly higher growth rate and formed more and larger colonies than the control cells.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>In addition, our in vivo studies indicated that the lenti-BI-1-infected cells formed obvious tumours, while no tumours were formed by the control cells after subcutaneously injected into nude mice.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cancer
Cancer
Cell

text: <ALL>These results strongly suggested that the BI-1 gene might play a crucial role in neoplastic genesis and development.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>p21 delays tumor onset by preservation of chromosomal stability.  </ALL>
label: Cancer
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>The p53 protein suppresses tumorigenesis by initiating cellular functions such as cell cycle arrest and apoptosis in response to DNA damage.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>A p53 mutant, p53R172P, which is deficient for apoptosis but retains a partial cell cycle arrest function, delays tumor onset in mice.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cancer

text: <ALL>Remarkably, lymphomas arising in Trp53(515C/515C) mice (encoding p53R172P) retain stable genomes.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Given the dominant role of p21 in p53 cell cycle control, we crossed Trp53(515C/515C) mice onto a p21-null background to determine whether p21 was required for maintaining chromosomal stability and delaying tumor onset.</ALL>
label: Cell
CellularComponent
Cancer

text: <ALL>Loss of p21 completely abolished the cell cycle arrest function of p53R172P and accelerated tumor onset in Trp53(515C/515C) mice.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cancer

text: <ALL>Cytogenetic examination of Trp53(515C/515C) p21(-/-)</ALL>
<ALL>sarcomas and lymphomas revealed aneuploidy and chromosomal aberrations that were absent in Trp53(515C/515C) malignancies.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>Thus, p21 coupled p53-dependent checkpoint control and preservation of chromosomal stability, and cooperated with apoptosis in suppressing tumor onset in mice.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
Cancer

text: <ALL>Osteonectin transcript and metastatic behavior in v-Ki-ras transformed fibroblasts.  </ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Osteonectin is one of the major non-collagenous proteins of bone.</ALL>
label: Tissue

text: <ALL>However, its transcript has been found in many soft, extracellular matrix-producing tissues; an osteonectin-related protein was detected in tumor basement membrane.</ALL>
label: Tissue
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>We have investigated the expression of osteonectin gene in fresh BALB/c fibroblasts transformed by v-Ki-ras.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Transformed cells exhibited lower levels of RNA as compared with normal fibroblasts.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>The transformed cells were cloned after in vivo tumorigenic assay, and 4 clones were analyzed for osteonectin expression by Northern blots.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>Two of them were selected for high or low osteonectin expression and tested in vivo in spontaneous and artificial metastasis assays.</ALL>
<ALL>High osteonectin expression was correlated with high lung colonization.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>When 10(5) cells were injected i.v., median colony value was 55 and 20 in higher expressor vs. lower expressor respectively (p less than 0.005).</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>Spontaneous metastasis indicates a possible reverse correlation.</ALL>
<ALL>Our data align osteonectin with other matrix-components and adhesion molecules in affecting potential metastatic spreading of transformed cells.</ALL>

text: <ALL>Retrospective case series of juxtafoveal choroidal neovascularization treated with photodynamic therapy with verteporfin.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>PURPOSE:</ALL>
<ALL>To describe visual acuity and angiographic outcomes of juxtafoveal choroidal neovascularization (CNV) treated with photodynamic therapy and verteporfin (PDT).</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure

text: <ALL>METHODS: Four hundred eighty-four consecutive eyes of 446 patients treated with PDT from January 1, 2001, to June 30, 2002, were identified from billing records.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Fluorescein angiograms were reviewed retrospectively to identify juxtafoveal CNV.</ALL>
<ALL>Eligible patients had CNV in which the central boundary of the lesion was between 1 and 199 microm from the geometric center of the foveal avascular zone (FAZ).</ALL>
label: Tissue
Tissue

text: <ALL>Patient charts were reviewed for visual acuity of the treated eye before PDT and at 6- and 12-month follow-up examinations.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Presence of subfoveal CNV at 6 and 12 months of follow-up was determined by review of fluorescein angiograms.</ALL>
<ALL>A lesion was considered subfoveal if it extended underneath the geometric center of the FAZ.</ALL>
label: Tissue

text: <ALL>RESULTS: Twenty-one eyes had juxtafoveal CNV.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Median change in visual acuity both 6 and 12 months after the initial PDT was 0 lines (n = 18 at 6 months, range -14 to + 8 lines; n = 17 at 12 months, range -18 to + 7 lines).</ALL>
<ALL>Eleven lesions progressed to a subfoveal location by 12 months.</ALL>
<ALL>Visual acuity in eyes with progressive lesions decreased a median of 4 lines of vision.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>CONCLUSIONS:</ALL>
<ALL>Despite a small sample size and limited length of follow-up, this study shows that visual acuity on average can remain stable for at least 12 months after PDT of juxtafoveal lesions.</ALL>
<ALL>Growth through the foveal center still can occur, however, and this can be associated with substantial visual loss.</ALL>
label: Tissue

text: <ALL>Loss of CDC4/FBXW7 in gastric carcinoma.  </ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>BACKGROUND: CDC4/FBXW7, encoding a ubiquitin ligase, maps to 4q32 and has been implicated as a tumor suppressor gene and therapeutic target in many tumor types.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>Mutations in colonic adenomas, and the frequent losses on 4q described in gastric cancer prompt speculation about the role of CDC4/FBXW7 in gastric carcinogenesis.</ALL>
label: Cancer
CellularComponent
Cancer
Organ

text: <ALL>METHODS:</ALL>

<ALL>We assessed the role of CDC4/FBXW7 in gastric cancer, through loss of heterozygosity (LOH) and multiplex ligation-dependent probe amplification (MLPA) on 47 flow-sorted gastric carcinomas including early-onset gastric cancers (EOGC) and xenografted conventional gastric carcinomas.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer
Cancer
Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>Ploidy analysis was carried out on 39 EOGCs and immunohistochemistry of CDC4/FBXW7 and its substrates c-myc, c-jun, Notch and cyclin E was performed on 204 gastric carcinomas using tissue microarrays (TMAs).</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer
Tissue

text: <ALL>Sequence analysis of CDC4/FBXW7 was carried out on gastric carcinoma cell lines and xenografts.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cancer

text: <ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>
<ALL>Loss of heterozygosity of CDC4/FBXW7 occurred in 32% of EOGCs, and correlated with loss of expression in 26%.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Loss of expression was frequent in both EOGC and conventional gastric cancers.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>No CDC4/FBXW7 mutations were found and loss of CDC4/FBXW7 did not correlate with ploidy status.</ALL>
<ALL>There was a significant correlation between loss of CDC4/FBXW7 expression and upregulation of c-myc.</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSION:</ALL>

<ALL>Loss of CDC4/FBXW7 appears to play a role in both EOGC and conventional gastric carcinogenesis, and c-myc overexpression is likely to be an important oncogenic consequence of CDC4/FBXW7 loss.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The tyrosine kinase inhibitor cediranib blocks ligand-induced vascular endothelial growth factor receptor-3 activity and lymphangiogenesis.</ALL>
<ALL>Solid tumors express a range of factors required to sustain their growth and promote their dissemination.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Among these are vascular endothelial growth factor-A (VEGF-A), the key angiogenic stimulant, and VEGF-C, a primary mediator of lymphangiogenesis.</ALL>
<ALL>Small molecule tyrosine kinase inhibitors offer the potential to inhibit more than one kinase and impede tumor growth by multiple mechanisms.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>However, their potency toward individual targets can vary.</ALL>

<ALL>Cediranib (RECENTIN; AZD2171) is an inhibitor of VEGF signaling that has been shown in experimental models to prevent VEGF-A-induced angiogenesis and primary tumor growth, yet the effects of cediranib on VEGF receptor (VEGFR)-3-mediated endothelial cell function and lymphangiogenesis are unknown.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cell

text: <ALL>To better understand the activity of cediranib against VEGFR-3 and its associated signaling events compared with its activity against VEGFR-2, we used the receptor-specific ligands VEGF-E and VEGF-C156S.</ALL>

<ALL>In human endothelial cells, cediranib inhibited VEGF-E-induced phosphorylation of VEGFR-2 and VEGF-C156S-induced phosphorylation of VEGFR-3 at concentrations of  less than /=1nmol/L and inhibited activation of downstream signaling molecules.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Additionally, cediranib blocked VEGF-C156S-induced and VEGF-E-induced proliferation, survival, and migration of lymphatic and blood vascular endothelial cells.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>In vivo, cediranib (6 mg/kg/d) prevented angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis induced by VEGF-E-expressing and VEGF-C156S-expressing adenoviruses, respectively.</ALL>

<ALL>Cediranib (6 mg/kg/day) also blocked angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis induced by adenoviruses expressing VEGF-A or VEGF-C and compromised the blood and lymphatic vasculatures of VEGF-C-expressing tumors.</ALL>
label: MultiTissueStructure
Cancer

text: <ALL>Cediranib may, therefore, be an effective means of preventing tumor progression, not only by inhibiting VEGFR-2 activity and angiogenesis, but also by concomitantly inhibiting VEGFR-3 activity and lymphangiogenesis.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Lack of developmental and reproductive toxicity of 2,3,3',4, 4'-pentachlorobiphenyl (PCB 105) in ring-necked pheasants.</ALL>
<ALL>Mono-ortho PCBs are global contaminants of wildlife with the potential to produce toxicity by an aryl hydrocarbon receptor (AhR)-mediated mechanism.</ALL>

<ALL>To determine the potency of 2,3,3',4, 4'-pentachlorobiphenyl (PCB 105) for producing reproductive and developmental toxicity, adult ring-necked pheasant hens (Phasianus colchicus) were orally dosed with 0, 0.06, 0.6, or 6 mg PCB 105/kg hen/week for 10 weeks to achieve cumulative doses of 0, 0.6, 6, or 60 mg PCB 105/kg hen after which hens were bred with untreated roosters once per week for 8 weeks.</ALL>

<ALL>Except at week 6 of the egg-laying period when cumulative egg production in the 6 mg PCB 105/kg hen group was greater than controls, fertilized egg production was not significantly different between treatment groups.</ALL>
<ALL>Embryo mortality and chick mortality were not significantly different between treatment groups.</ALL>

<ALL>Total body and heart weights of all chicks 1 day posthatch (dph) were not different between groups, however, liver weights of chicks from the 60 mg/kg treatment group were greater than controls at 1 dph.</ALL>
label: Organ
Organ

text: <ALL>The first chick to hatch from each hen was reared to 21 dph and among these birds, the total body, liver, and heart weights were not different between groups.</ALL>
label: Organ
Organ

text: <ALL>There were no dose-related malformations of the beak or limbs, and no signs of subcutaneous edema, ascites, or pericardial edema in chicks at 1 or 21 dph.</ALL>
<ALL>Hepatic microsomal monooxygenase activities</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>[ethoxyresorufin-O-dealkylase (EROD), benzyloxyresorufin-O-dealkylase (BROD), and methyloxyresorufin-O-dealkylase (MROD)] were significantly elevated in chicks at 1 dph from hens given a cumulative PCB 105 dose of 6 mg/kg and in chicks at 21 dph from hens given a cumulative PCB dose of 60 mg/kg.</ALL>

<ALL>These results indicate that a cumulative PCB 105 dose up to 60 mg/kg hen does not decrease the production of fertilized eggs or increase embryo or chick mortality in ring-necked pheasants, but does increase chick hepatic monooxygenase activity.</ALL>
label: Organ

text: <ALL>Apoptosis induced by 1'-acetoxychavicol acetate in Ehrlich ascites tumor cells is associated with modulation of polyamine metabolism and caspase-3 activation.  </ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>The efficacy of the antitumor activity of 1'-acetoxychavicol acetate (ACA), reported to be a suppressor of chemically induced carcinogenesis, was evaluated in Ehrlich ascites tumor cells.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cell

text: <ALL>ACA treatment resulted in changes in morphology and a dose-dependent suppression of cell viability.</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Apoptosis, characterized by nuclear condensation, membrane blebbing, cell shrinkage and a significant induction of caspase-3-like protease activity at 8 h in a time-course study were observed.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
CellularComponent
Cell

text: <ALL>Formation of apoptotic bodies was preceded by lowering of intracellular polyamines, particularly putrescine, and both dose- and time-dependent inhibitory and activation effect by ACA on ornithine decarboxylase (ODC) and spermidine/spermine N(1)-acetyltransferase (SSAT), respectively.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>Administration of exogenous polyamines prevented ACA-induced apoptosis represented by a reduction in the number of apoptotic bodies and also caused reduction in the induced caspase-3-like protease activity at 8 h. These findings suggest that the anticarcinogenic effects of ACA might be partly due to perturbation of the polyamine metabolic pathway and triggering of caspase-3-like activity, which result in apoptosis.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>The in vivo properties of STX243: a potent angiogenesis inhibitor in breast cancer.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The steroidal-based drug 2-ethyloestradiol-3,17-O,O-bis-sulphamate (STX243) has been developed as a potent antiangiogenic and antitumour compound.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The objective of this study was to ascertain whether STX243 is more active in vivo than the clinically relevant drug 2-methoxyoestradiol (2-MeOE2) and the structurally similar compound 2-MeOE2-3,17-O,O-bis-sulphamate (STX140).</ALL>
<ALL>The tumour growth inhibition efficacy, antiangiogenic potential and pharmacokinetics of STX243 were examined using four in vivo models.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Both STX243 and STX140 were capable of retarding the growth of MDA-MB-231 xenograft tumours (72 and 63%, respectively), whereas no inhibition was observed for animals treated with 2-MeOE2.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Further tumour inhibition studies showed that STX243 was also active against MCF-7 paclitaxel-resistant tumours.</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>Using a Matrigel plug-based model, in vivo angiogenesis was restricted with STX243 and STX140 (50 and 72%, respectively, using a 10 mg kg(-1) oral dose), thereby showing the antiangiogenic activity of both compounds.</ALL>
<ALL>The pharmacokinetics of STX243 were examined at two different doses using adult female rats.</ALL>
<ALL>The compound was orally bioavailable (31% after a single 10 mg kg(-1) dose) and resistant to metabolism.</ALL>
<ALL>These results show that STX243 is a potent in vivo drug and could be clinically effective at treating a number of oncological conditions.</ALL>
<ALL>Effects of growth temperature, 47-megadalton plasmid, and calcium deficiency on the outer membrane protein porin and lipopolysaccharide composition of Yersinia pestis EV76.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>The expression of several virulence determinants of Yersinia pestis is known to be dependent on the in vitro growth temperature.</ALL>
<ALL>One of these, calcium dependence, is associated with the presence of a 47-megadalton plasmid.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>We have examined the effects of incubation temperature, calcium in the growth medium, the presence of the 47-megadalton plasmid on the outer membrane protein, and the lipopolysaccharide composition of Y. pestis EV76.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>When cells were grown at 37 degrees C as opposed to 26 degrees C, a change in lipopolysaccharide composition and a decrease in the amount of an outer membrane protein (protein E) were observed.</ALL>
label: Cell
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>The lipopolysaccharide obtained from cells incubated at 37 degrees C had a lower proportion of 2 keto-3-deoxyoctanate, a lower phosphate to 2-keto-3-deoxyoctanate ratio, and an increased gel mobility upon sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis when compared with lipopolysaccharide obtained from cells grown at 26 degrees C. Because of its growth temperature-related abundance, we investigated the nature of protein E.</ALL>
label: Cell
Cell

text: <ALL>This protein had physical properties similar to those of other enterobacterial porins, including apparent formation of an oligomer on sodium dodecyl sulfate-polyacrylamide gels when solubilized at low temperature, acidic isoelectric point, and strong noncovalent association with the peptidoglycan.</ALL>
<ALL>Protein E was purified and shown to form an aqueous channel in planar lipid membranes with a conductance of 1.1 nS in 1 M KCl.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>In addition to growth temperature-related alterations in the lipopolysaccharide and porin components of the outer membrane, the amount of three spots in two-dimensional polyacrylamide gels was shown to be related to the temperature or the presence of calcium during growth.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent

text: <ALL>One of these spots was shown to contain residual unmodified portions of two major heat-modifiable proteins which failed to shift to their heat-modified positions on gels, despite solubilization at 100 degrees C for 10 min before electrophoresis.</ALL>
<ALL>The other two spots were the heat-modified and unmodified forms of another outer membrane protein (J) which did not appear in the isoelectric focusing gel of cells grown at 37 degrees C.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
Cell

text: <ALL>It is proposed that the appearance of these spots in two-dimensional analyses is related to the lipopolysaccharide composition of the cells from which the outer membrane is derived and reflects lipopolysaccharide-protein interactions or calcium-protein interactions.</ALL>
label: Cell
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>[The clinical and laboratory features of acute promyelocytic leukemia: an analysis of 513 cases].</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>OBJECTIVE: To investigate the clinical and laboratory features of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL).</ALL>
label: Cancer
Cancer

text: <ALL>METHODS: 513 APL patients in the last two decades were retrospectively analyzed in this research.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>We investigated the clinical features including age, sex, abnormality of peripheral hemogram before treatment, therapeutic effect and follow-up and laboratory data such as morphology, immunology, cytogenetics and molecular biology (MICM).</ALL>
<ALL>RESULTS:</ALL>
<ALL>The median age of the APL patients was 33 years old and the ratio of male and female was 1.21:1.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>Before treatment, the median level of WBC was 4.3 x 10(9)/L and the detection rate of abnormal promyelocyte on blood film was 85.8%; with immunophenotypic detection, the expression levels of CD117, CD34, HLA-DR, CD7, CD14 and CD19 in APL were found to be lower and the expression levels of CD2, CD33 and MPO higher than those in other subtypes of acute myelocytic leukemia (AML) (both P < 0.01).</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>Specific abnormal chromosome t (15;17) was detected in 91.7% of the patients, of whom 75.9% had standard translocation of t (15;17), being the most common one and 15.8% of the patients had t (15;17) with additional abnormal chromosome.</ALL>
label: CellularComponent
CellularComponent

text: <ALL>There was only 7.5% of the patients with normal karyotype.</ALL>
<ALL>However, the presence of both simple translocation and complex translocation was seldom seen.</ALL>
<ALL>With molecular biological detection, PML/RARalpha fusion gene positive rate was 99.6%.</ALL>
<ALL>In a relatively long clinical follow-up, we found that the complete remission (CR) rate in APL patients was 84.7%, incidence of DIC was 13.4% and five-year survival rate was 30.7%.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The median count of WBC in CR group was lower than that non-remission group (P < 0.01).</ALL>
label: Cell

text: <ALL>There were no significant differences on expressions of CD34 and CD2 and changes of cytogenetics between the two groups (P > 0.05).</ALL>
<ALL>CONCLUSIONS:</ALL>
<ALL>Comprehensive evaluation of MICM could be of important significance in the diagnosis and prognosis judgment for APL patients.</ALL>
label: Cancer

text: <ALL>The CR rate in these patients with high WBC count was considerable low.</ALL>
